title: Complex UI/UX Problem Quiz
description: Test your understanding of approaches to solving complex front-end challenges.

questions.question: What is the first step in solving a complex UI/UX problem?

options.text: Start coding immediately to build momentum
Clearly define the problem and understand the user's needs
Choose the most advanced technology to solve it
Look for a library that already solves it

questions.explanation: Before writing any code, you need to understand the problem thoroughly: who are the users, what are they trying to accomplish, what constraints exist, and what does success look like?

questions.question: Which API is most appropriate for implementing infinite scroll?
questions.explanation: IntersectionObserver efficiently detects when a sentinel element enters the viewport, triggering the next data load. It's more performant than scroll event listeners because it runs off the main thread.

questions.question: The best solution to a complex UI problem is always the most technically sophisticated one.
questions.explanation: The best solution balances user needs, performance, maintainability, and development cost. Sometimes a simpler approach is more appropriate than a technically impressive one.

questions.question: When presenting a complex problem you solved in an interview, what should you emphasize?

options.text: Only the final solution and technologies used
Your thought process, trade-offs considered, and how you measured success
How many lines of code you wrote

questions.explanation: Interviewers want to understand your problem-solving approach: how you break down complexity, evaluate trade-offs, iterate on solutions, and validate results. The process matters more than the final answer.

questions.question: Which technique helps make data tables usable on mobile devices?

options.text: Making all text smaller to fit the screen
Horizontal scrolling, stacking rows as cards, or prioritizing visible columns
Hiding the table completely on mobile

questions.explanation: Responsive data tables can use several strategies: horizontal scroll with sticky first column, transforming rows into stacked cards, or showing only priority columns with a 'show more' toggle. The best approach depends on the data and user needs.
